{{DISPLAYTITLE:husITa}} '''husITa''' (Human Services Information Technology Applications) is an international virtual association{{spnd}}and a registered US non-profit organization{{spnd}}established with the mission of promoting the ethical and effective use of [[information technology]] in the [[human services]]. The main focus of husITa, and the claim to expertise of its associates, is situated at the intersection of three core domains: [[information technology]], [[human services]], and [[social development]]. husITa pursues its mission through international conferences, publications and research dissemination directed at technology applications and innovations that promote social well-being.
For much of its early history husITa operated as an informal international network of human service academics and practitioners. One of the outcomes of its first international conference{{spnd}}husITa1 held in 1987 in [[Birmingham]], England{{spnd}}was the establishment of a working group to determine the feasibility of an international body 'to highlight the importance of human service computing, to guide developments, and to foster international co-operation'.
The working group was composed of Hein de Graaf (Netherlands), Walter LaMendola (USA), Dick Schoech (USA), and Stuart Toole (UK). Initial projects identified by the working group included the development of research agendas, position papers, repositories of information, and promoting a second husITa conference in 1989. Bryan Glastonbury was later added to the group as secretary. The working group met in Colorado, Denver for three days in May 1988 and published a report on the issues that a husITa international organization would need to address.<ref>See Report of the husITa working group, Computer Use in Social Services Network Newsletter, Fall, 1998, Vol 8/3, pp. 6-9</ref>
Although the 1988 Denver meeting agreed its objectives, husITa wasn't formally established as an organization for another twelve years. The structure of the formal organization was later agreed to at Denver in 2000. The founding members at the Denver 2000 meeting were: Hein de Graaf, Walter LaMendola, Rob MacFadden, Jo Ann Regan, Jackie Rafferty, Jan Steyaert, Dick Schoech, Stuart Toole, and Victor Savtschenko.
== Objectives == husITa's objectives (agreed by the 1988 Denver working group) are to: * Facilitate international cooperation in human service technology. * Collect and disseminate information on human service technology, including tackling the problems of language translation. * Provide technical assistance in human service technology and encourage the involvement of countries with a less developed human service IT infrastructure. * Stimulate international discussion on key human service technology issues and encourage position papers in areas such as security/privacy/confidentiality, curriculum content and teaching methods, and ethical issues in systems/software development and use. * Encourage publications about human service information technology. * Encourage international research efforts. * Encourage standards for making human service technology culturally independent.
== Journal of Technology in Human Services == The [http://www.tandfonline.com/action/aboutThisJournal?show=aimsScope&journalCode=wths20 ''Journal of Technology in Human Services''] is the official journal of husITa. Formerly known as ''Computers in Human Services'' it was launched in 1985 as a [[Haworth Press]] publication.<ref>The journal [http://www.tandfonline.com/toc/wzch20/1/1 Computers in Human Services]</ref> Dick Schoech, a professor of social work at the [[University of Texas at Arlington]], was its founding editor. The ''Journal of Technology in Human Services'' is a peer-reviewed, refereed journal now published by [[Taylor & Francis]]. Its scope includes the potential of information and communication technologies in mental health, developmental disability, welfare, addictions, education, and other human services. The current Editor-in-Chief is [http://www.laurigoldkind.net/ Dr. Lauri Goldkind] (Associate Professor, Fordham University, USA), with [http://apss.polyu.edu.hk/staff/dr-chan-chitat-chen-zhi-da-bo-shi Dr. Chitat Chan] (Assistant Professor, Hong Kong Polytechnic University, Hong Kong) serves as the Associate Editor-in-Chief.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Journal of Technology in Human Services Turns a New Page|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/15228835.2017.1356996|accessdate=7 September 2017}}</ref>
== International conferences ==
'''husITa1''': husITa's first international conference was held between in September 1987 in [[Birmingham]], England.<ref>Selected papers from husITa 1 were published in Glastonbury, LaMendola & Toole (1988). [https://books.google.com/books?id=tD9HAAAAMAAJ&q=Information+Technology+and+the+Human+Services&dq=Information+Technology+and+the+Human+Services&source=bl&ots=HcMF0O2XXA&sig=ZOFVk89KT9RdsLgT-gEmb5NmRbk&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Z8CAUMmEMMKhigeXoYGIBQ&ved=0CDsQ6AEwAQ Information Technology and the Human Services]. Chichester, England: John Wiley & Sons</ref>
'''husITa2''': ''Computer Technology and Human Services in the 90’s: Advancing Theory and Practice'', June 1991 in [[New Brunswick, New Jersey]].<ref>Selected papers from husITa 2 were published in Leiderman, M. Guzetta, C., Struminger, L., Monnickendam, M. (Eds.). (1993). [https://books.google.com/books?id=dO7fdRjZ5xUC&lpg=PP1&ots=l58tFC9hCP&dq=Technology%20in%20People%20Services&pg=PP1#v=onepage&q=Technology%20in%20People%20Services&f=false Technology in People Services]. New York: Haworth Press</ref>
'''husITa3''': ''Information Technology and the Quality of Life and Services'', June 1993 in [[Maastricht]], the Netherlands.<ref>Selected papers from husITa3 were published in [http://www.tandfonline.com/toc/wzch20/12/1-2 Computers in Human Services, Volume 12 (½)]</ref> The same year saw the formation of a husITa Foundation in the Netherlands which continued until its disestablishment in 2003.
'''husITa4''': ''Information Technology in the Human Services: Dreams and Realities'', June 1996 in [[Lapland, Finland]].<ref>Selected papers from husITa 4 were published in Glastonbury, B. (1996). [https://books.google.com/books/about/Dreams_and_Realities.html?id=GZdSAAAACAAJ&redir_esc=y Dreams and Realities: Information Technology in the Human Services]. Helsinki, Finland:Stakes.</ref>
'''husITa5''': ''Social Services in the Information Society: Closing the GAP'', August–September 1999 in [[Budapest]], Hungary.
'''husITa6''': ''Technology and Human Services in a Multicultural Society'', September 2001, in [[Charleston, South Carolina]]. However, the conference was cut short as a result of the terrorist attacks in the USA on 11 September 2001. A brief husITa board meeting was held, the by-laws were approved, and officers were elected.
'''husITa7''': ''Digital Inclusion-Building a Digital Inclusive Society'', August 2004 in [[Hong Kong]], China.<ref>Selected papers from HUSITA7 were published in Law, Wong & Fung (2007). [https://www.amazon.com/HUSITA7-The-International-Conference-Information-Technology/dp/0789033720 ''HUSITA7-The 7th International Conference of Human Services Information Technology'']. London: Routledge</ref> It had been delayed from its planned date of 2003 due to an outbreak of [[SARS]].
'''husITa8''': ''Information Technology and Diversity in Human Services: Promoting Strength Through Difference'', August 2007 in [[Toronto]], Canada.<ref>The website for [http://www.web.net/~husita8/ HUSITA8]</ref>
'''husITa9''': ''ICT as a Context for Human Services'', June 2010 in [[Hong Kong]], China. This event was held in conjunction with the 2010 Joint World Conference on Social Work and Social Development.
'''husITa14''': ''Sustainable & Ethical use of Technology''. July 9–12, Melbourne, Australia. Held in conjunction with the 2014 Joint World Conference on Social Work, Education, and Social Development.
== Related human service technology initiatives == husITa was built on the activity of an international network of human service organizations, academics and practitioners in the USA, the UK and the Netherlands. The section below highlights some of the key organizations, people and events.
=== Early developments ===
In 1978, Gunther R. Geiss, aprofessor of social work at [[Adelphi University]], New York, conducted a survey of US schools of [[social work]]. The survey sought to identify faculty members who had used computers in their administrative, teaching or research activities, or who had consulted or participated in the design and development of computer-based information systems. There were over 80 positive responses indicating a wide range of activities and levels of involvement. The survey initiated the development of a system to track and communicate with individuals with expertise in computers and human services.
Walter LaMendola, professor of social work at the [[University of Denver]] in Colorado, described an incident during a social work conference in 1979 suggesting early indications of the resistance of some social work professionals to computer use in the human services.<ref>Walter LaMendola discusses '[http://wweb.uta.edu/faculty/schoech/cussn/stories.htm crowd resistance]' to a human services computer presentation in 1979.</ref> This is a theme which has continued throughout the history of technology use in the human services and continues to the present day. Some aspects of this resistance can be considered as a well-founded concern about the ethical issues surrounding human service technology applications. However, other aspects of technology resistance seem to be a less rational form of [[Neo-Luddism]].
=== Computer Use in Social Services Network (CUSSN) === Growing interest in the use of technology in the human services led a group of US human service technology specialists, meeting at a [http://www.cswe.org/ Council of Social Work Education] conference in [[Louisville, Kentucky|Louisville]] Kentucky in 1981, to form the Computer Use In Social Services Network ([http://wweb.uta.edu/faculty/schoech/cussn/cussn/index.htm CUSSN]). By the end of 1981 the network had over 350 members. The CUSSN newsletter continued in print until 1992 when it was merged with the first academic journal on human service technology ''Computers in Human Services''.
In 1984 Gunther Geiss was sponsored by the [http://www.socialservicegrants.org/silbermanfund.html Silberman Fund] to organize the Wye Plantation Conference on Human Services Technology. Conference members developed pre-conference position papers via EYES: a centralized email system.<ref>Papers from the Wye Plantation Conference were published in [https://www.amazon.com/Human-Edge-Information-Technology-Helping/dp/0866564047/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1350877770&sr=1-1&keywords=0866564047 Geiss & Viswanathan (1995)]</ref>
In 1985, CUSSN developed CUSSNet [http://psycnet.apa.org/psycinfo/1992-17472-001 CUSSNet], a PC and [[FidoNet]] based networking system that automatically exchanged emails between members each night during off-peak telephone hours. [[FidoNet]] was a PC distributed email, bulletin board, and file sharing system that preceded the Internet. CUSSNet quickly developed nodes in major cities in the US, the UK, and the Netherlands.
The name husITa (Human Service Information Technology Applications) was coined in 1983 by Walter LaMendola and Brian Klepinger at the [[University of Denver]].
The Human Service [[Microcomputer]] Conference was held in [[Seattle]].
=== Computer Applications in Social Work (CASW) === In 1984 Stuart Toole formed Computer Applications in Social Work (CASW) in the UK to set up and run national conferences and to publish the CASW journal.
Based on the success of the first UK technology conferences, Stuart Toole, Walter LaMendola, and Brian Klepinger agreed to pursue an international conference in 1987: this conference was to become HUSITA's first international conference HUSITA1.
The CASW journal was later renamed [http://www.southampton.ac.uk/chst/projects/nths_archive/default.htm New Technology in the Human Services] in [when] and continued in publication under this title until it was closed in 2003.
In 1986 the second UK conference held on [[social welfare]] computing was held.
=== The Centre for Human Service Technology (CHST) === In 1985 Bryan Glastonbury, from the University of Southampton published ''Computers in Social Work'', the first major academic text on technology and human services.<ref>Glastonbury, B. (1985). Computers in Social Work. London, England: MacMillan.</ref> In the same year the [[University of Southampton]] began publishing the journal New Technology in the Human Services under the editorship of Bryan Glastonbury. In the same year the University of Southampton established the Centre for Human Service Technology (CHST) with Jackie Rafferty as Director. In 2007, Jan Steyaert joined as adjunct research professor and together they edited a special issue of the British Journal of Social Work on ''social work in the digital age''. The [http://www.southampton.ac.uk/chst/ Centre for Human Service Technology] is based at the University of Southampton in England. CHST is an international, multi-disciplinary research center focused on influencing the appropriate use of technology in social work practice and education and researching its implementation and impact.
In July 1997 the CTI Centre for Human Services held a conference on ''Social Services and Learning Technology'' hosted by the Institute for Health and Community Services at the University of Bournemouth.
In 2003 the journal New Technology in Human Services ceased publication.
=== The European Network for Information Technology in Human Services (ENITH) === In 1986 Hein de Graaf, Director of the CREON foundation in the Netherlands, organised the first of a series of three-day gatherings. The CREON foundation was a Dutch foundation for computer research, expertise and support in field of the human services. The gatherings, called WELCOM, were designed to increase the knowledge and understanding of information technology in the Dutch human services. WELCOM1 was held in 1986 in [[Bussum]] with Walter LaMendola as the main international speaker. WELCOM2, a smaller Dutch-only conference, took place in 1987, again in [[Bussum]]. The next WELCOM event, WELCOM3: a combined conference and fair, was held jointly with HUSITA3 in [[Maastricht]] in 1993.
Following the success of HUSITA's first international conference held in Birmingham in 1987 the Dutch Ministry of Social Welfare, Health and Cultural Affairs organized an informal meeting of European experts in the field of Information Technology and Human Services. The meeting was one of the outcomes of a feasibility study carried out by the CREON foundation, concerning international cooperation in this field. A main conclusion of this feasibility study was that an international (European) network should be established for the exchange of products, ideas, expertise, experiences and skills with respect to the introduction and use of IT in the human services. As a first step in this approach the informal meeting of experts was organized. The European network of organizations was called ENITH (European Network Information Technology and Human services).<ref>This [http://wweb.uta.edu/projects/sswtech/husita/history/ENITH_experts.htm report of an Expert Meeting] held by the Dutch Ministry of Social Welfare, Health and Cultural Affairs details the early work of ENITH.</ref>
In 1992 an ENITH3 Expert Meeting on “IT Applications and the Quality of Life and Services” was held in The Netherlands.
In 1994, from September 21 to September 23 an ENITH4 conference was held in [[Berlin]], Germany. Bernd kolleck chaired this conference.
In September 1995 a CAUSA5/ENITH5 conference on “The Impact of Information Technology on Social Policy,” was held in Eindhoven, The Netherlands. Jan Steyaert chaired this conference.

ICB represents an ion-related counterpart of the better-known electronic '''[[Coulomb blockade]] (ECB)''' that is observed in [[Quantum dot|quantum dots]]'''.<ref name=":11">{{Cite journal|last=Averin|first=D. V.|last2=Likharev|first2=K. K.|date=1986-02-01|title=Coulomb blockade of single-electron tunneling, and coherent oscillations in small tunnel junctions|journal=Journal of Low Temperature Physics|language=en|volume=62|issue=3–4|pages=345–373|doi=10.1007/bf00683469|issn=0022-2291|bibcode=1986JLTP...62..345A}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Beenakker|first=C. W. J.|date=1991-07-15|title=Theory of Coulomb-blockade oscillations in the conductance of a quantum dot|journal=Physical Review B|volume=44|issue=4|pages=1646–1656|doi=10.1103/PhysRevB.44.1646|hdl=1887/3358|bibcode=1991PhRvB..44.1646B}}</ref>''' Both ICB and ECB arise from [[Charge quantization|quantisation of the electric charge]] and from an electrostatic exclusion principle and they share in common a number of effects and underlying physical mechanisms. ICB provides some specific effects related to the existence of ions of different valence <math>z</math> (different in both sign and value), in contrast to the single-valence electrons of ECB (<math>z=-1</math>). Coulomb blockade can also apear in superconductors; in such a case the free charge carriers are Cooper pairs (<math>z=-2</math>) <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Amar|first=A.|last2=Song|first2=D.|last3=Lobb|first3=C. J.|last4=Wellstood|first4=F. C.|date=1994-05-16|title=2e to e periodic pair currents in superconducting Coulomb-blockade electrometers|url=https://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevLett.72.3234|journal=Physical Review Letters|volume=72|issue=20|pages=3234–3237|doi=10.1103/PhysRevLett.72.3234}}</ref>
ICB effects appear in tiny pores whose [[self-capacitance]] <math>C_{\rm s}</math> is so small that the charging energy <math>\Delta E</math> of a single ion becomes large compared to the [[thermal energy]] per particle <math>k_{\rm B}T</math>. In such cases there is strong quantisation of the energy spectrum inside the pore, and the system may either be “blockaded” against the entry of any additional ions or, in the opposite extreme, it may show resonant barrier-less conduction,<ref name=":16" /><ref name="Kaufman:15" /> depending on the free energy bias coming from '''<math>Q_{\rm f}</math>''', <math>V</math>, or <math>\log{c_{\rm b}}</math>.
The ICB model claims that <math>Q_{\rm f}</math> is a primary determinant of conduction and selectivity for particular ions, and the predicted oscillations in conductance and an associated Coulomb staircase of channel occupancy ''vs'' <math>Q_{\rm f}</math><ref name="Kaufman:15" /> are expected to be strong effects in the cases of divalent ions or trivalent ions.
Some effects, now recognised as belonging to ICB, were discovered and considered earlier in precursor papers on electrostatics-governed conduction mechanisms in channels and nanopores.<ref>{{Citation|last=von Kitzing|first=Eberhard|date=1992|pages=297–314|publisher=Springer Netherlands|language=en|doi=10.1007/978-94-011-2718-9_25|isbn=9789401052054|chapter=A Novel Model for Saturation of Ion Conductivity in Transmembrane Channels|title=Membrane Proteins: Structures, Interactions and Models|volume=25|series=The Jerusalem Symposia on Quantum Chemistry and Biochemistry}}</ref> <ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Zhang|first=J.|last2=Kamenev|first2=A.|last3=Shklovskii|first3=B. I.|date=2006-05-19|title=Ion exchange phase transitions in water-filled channels with charged walls|journal=Physical Review E|volume=73|issue=5|pages=051205|doi=10.1103/PhysRevE.73.051205|pmid=16802926|arxiv=cond-mat/0510327|bibcode=2006PhRvE..73e1205Z}}</ref><ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=Roux|first=Benot|last2=Allen|first2=Toby|last3=Bernche|first3=Simon|last4=Im|first4=Wonpil|date=2004-02-01|title=Theoretical and computational models of biological ion channels|journal=Quarterly Reviews of Biophysics|volume=37|issue=1|pages=15–103|doi=10.1017/s0033583504003968|pmid=17390604|issn=0033-5835}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Yesylevskyy|first=S.O.|last2=Kharkyanen|first2=V.N.|date=2005-06-01|title=Barrier-less knock-on conduction in ion channels: peculiarity or general mechanism?|journal=Chemical Physics|volume=312|issue=1–3|pages=127–133|doi=10.1016/j.chemphys.2004.11.031|issn=0301-0104|bibcode=2005CP....312..127Y}}</ref><ref name="Corry:05">{{Cite journal|last=Corry|first=Ben|last2=Vora|first2=Taira|last3=Chung|first3=Shin-Ho|date=June 2005|title=Electrostatic basis of valence selectivity in cationic channels|journal=Biochimica et Biophysica Acta (BBA) - Biomembranes|volume=1711|issue=1|pages=72–86|doi=10.1016/j.bbamem.2005.03.002|pmid=15904665|issn=0005-2736}}</ref>
The manifestations of ICB have been observed in water-filled sub-nanometre pores through a 2D <chem>MoS2</chem> [[monolayer]],<ref name="Feng:16" /> revealed by Brownian dynamics (BD) simulations of calcium conductance bands in narrow channels,<ref name="Kaufman:15" /><ref name=":12" /> and account for a diversity of effects seen in biological [[ion channels]].<ref name="Kaufman:15" /> ICB predictions have also been confirmed by a mutation study of divalent blockade in the NaChBac bacterial channel<ref name=":8" />. == ICB model/theory ==
=== Generic electrostatic model of channel/nanopore === [[File:Jstat521809f01 hr.jpg|thumb|Fig. 1. Generic electrostatic and Brownian dynamics model of a channel or nanopore|330x330px|alt=]]ICB effects may be derived on the basis of a simplified electrostatics/Brownian dynamics model of a nanopore or of the selectivity filter of an ion channel.<ref name=":3" /> The model represents the channel/pore as a charged hole through a water-filled protein hub embedded in the membrane. Its fixed charge <math>Q_{\rm f}</math> is considered as a uniform, centrally placed, rigid ring (Fig.1). The channel is assumed to have geometrical parameters length <math>L\approx1</math>nm and radius <math>R\approx 0.3-0.5</math>nm, allowing for the single-file movement of partially hydrated ions.
The model represents the water and protein as continuous media with dielectric constants <math>\varepsilon_{\rm w}=80</math> and <math>\varepsilon_{\rm p}=2-10</math> respectively. The mobile ions are described as discrete entities with valence <math>z</math> and of radius <math>R_{\rm ion}</math>, moving stochastically through the pore, governed by the self-consistently coupled [[Poisson's equation|Poisson's electrostatic equation]] and [[Langevin equation|Langevin stochastic equation.]]
The model is applicable to both cationic<ref name=":4" /> and anionic<ref name=":15">{{Cite journal|last=Hartzell|first=Criss|last2=Putzier|first2=Ilva|last3=Arreola|first3=Jorge|date=2005-03-17|title=Calcium -activated chloride channels|journal=Annual Review of Physiology|language=en|volume=67|issue=1|pages=719–758|doi=10.1146/annurev.physiol.67.032003.154341|pmid=15709976|issn=0066-4278}}</ref> biological ion channels and to artificial nanopores.<ref name=":0" /><ref name="Feng:16" />
=== Basic electrostatics of ICB === The  mobile ion is assumed to be partially hydrated  (typically retaining its first [[hydration shell]] <ref name=":13" />) and carrying charge <math>q=ze</math> where <math>e</math> is the elementary charge (e.g. the <math>\text{Ca}^{2+}</math> ion with <math>z=2</math>). The model allows one to derive the pore and ion parameters satisfying the barrier-less permeation conditions, and to do so from basic electrostatics taking account of [[Charge quantization|charge quantisation.]]
The potential energy <math>E_n</math> of a channel/pore containing <math>n </math> ions can be decomposed into electrostatic energy<ref name=":0" /><ref name="Kaufman:15" /><ref name=":3" /><math>E_{n}^{\rm ES}</math> , dehydration energy,<ref name=":13">{{Cite journal|last=Zwolak|first=Michael|last2=Wilson|first2=James|last3=Ventra|first3=Massimiliano Di|date=2010|title=Dehydration and ionic conductance quantization in nanopores|url=http://stacks.iop.org/0953-8984/22/i=45/a=454126|journal=Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter|language=en|volume=22|issue=45|pages=454126|doi=10.1088/0953-8984/22/45/454126|pmid=21152075|pmc=2997750|issn=0953-8984|bibcode=2010JPCM...22S4126Z|arxiv=1005.2550}}</ref> <math>E_n^{\rm DH}</math> and ion-ion local interaction energy <math>E_n^{\rm INT}</math>:<math display="block">E_n=E_n^{\rm ES}+E_n^{\rm DH}+E_n^{\rm INT}...(E_n \text{ Decomposition})</math> The basic ICB model makes the simplifying approximation that <math>E_n=E_n^{ES}</math>, whence:<math display="block">\begin{align} Q_n & = z n e+Q_{\rm f} &\text{(Excess charge)}\\ E_n&=\dfrac{Q_n^2}{2C_s} &\text{(Electrostatic energy)} \\ C_s& = 4\pi \epsilon_0 \epsilon_w \dfrac{R^2}{L} &\text{(Self-capacitance)} \end{align} </math>where <math>Q_{n}</math> is the net charge of the pore when it contains <math>n</math> identical ions of valence <math>z</math>, the sign of the moving ions being opposite to that of the <math>Q_{\rm f}</math>, <math>C_{\rm s} </math> represents the electrostatic self-capacitance of the pore, and <math>\epsilon_0</math> is the electric permittivity of the vacuum.
=== Resonant barrier-less conduction === [[File:Resonant barrier-less conduction.svg|thumb|330x330px|Fig.2. Resonant barrier-less conduction of <chem>Ca^{2+}</chem>ions, with energies <math>E</math> plotted vertically. (a) Plot of <math>\mu_{\rm ex}</math>as a function of fixed charge <math>Q_{\rm f}/e</math> and position <math>x</math> in the channel. At the "resonant" value of <math>Q_{\rm f}/e=1</math> the transition is almost barrier-less (red cross-section). (b) Plots of <math>\Delta E</math> (blue curve) and <math>E_{\rm AFF}</math> (dashed-green) and their sum <math>\mu_{\rm ex}</math> (red) against <math>x</math> for <math>Q_{\rm f}/e=1</math>, showing that barrier-less conduction originates in a near-cancellation between <math>\Delta E</math> and <math>E_{\rm AFF}</math>.|alt=|left]]
Thermodynamics and statistical mechanics describe systems that have variable numbers of particles via the [[chemical potential]] <math>\mu </math>, defined as Gibbs free energy <math>G</math> per particle <ref name=":14" /> <ref name=":5" /> :<math display="block">\begin{align} G_n&=E_n-TS_n & \text{(Gibbs free energy)}\\ \mu_n&=G_{n+1}-G_n &\text{(Chemical potential)} \end{align} </math>, where <math>G_n </math> is the Gibbs free energy for the system of <math>n</math> particles. In thermal and particle equilibrium with bulk reservoirs, the entire system has a common value of chemical potential <math>\mu=\mu_F </math> (the [[Fermi level]] in other contexts).<ref name=":14" /> The free energy needed for the entry of a new ion to the channel is defined by the [[excess chemical potential]] <math>\mu_{\rm ex}=\mu_n-\mu_F</math><ref name=":14">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=NaQ-AwAAQBAJ&lpg=PP1&dq=landsberg%20statistical%20mechanics%202014&pg=PP1#v=onepage&q=landsberg%20statistical%20mechanics%202014&f=false|title=Thermodynamics and Statistical Mechanics|last=Landsberg|first=Peter T.|date=2014-03-05|publisher=Courier Corporation|isbn=9780486167589|language=en}}</ref> which (ignoring an entropy term ) can be written as <math display="block">\begin{align} \mu_{\rm ex}&=E_{n+1}-E_n=\Delta E+E_{\rm AFF} &\text{(Coulomb gap)}\\ \Delta E&= \frac{ze}{2}\phi_{\rm s}; \quad \phi_s=\dfrac{ze}{C_{\rm s}} &\text{(Charging energy)}\\ E_{\rm AFF}&=\phi_s Q_n =\phi_{\rm s}(zen+Q_{\rm f}) &\text{(Affinity energy)} \end{align} </math> where <math>\Delta E</math> is the charging energy (self-energy barrier) of an incoming ion, <math>\phi_s </math> is the self-potential of ion and <math> E_{\rm AFF} </math>is its affinity (i.e. energy of attraction to the binding site <math>Q_{\rm f}</math>). The difference in energy between <math>\Delta E</math> and <math>\Delta E_{\rm AFF}</math> (Fig.2.) defines the ionic energy level separation ([[Coulomb gap]]) and give rise to most of the observed ICB effects.
In selective ion channels, the favoured ionic species passes through the channel almost at the rate of free [[diffusion]], despite the strong affinity to the binding site. This '''conductivity-selectivty paradox''' has been explained as being a consequaence of selective barrier-less conduction<ref name=":16">{{Cite journal|last=Eisenman|first=George|last2=Horn|first2=Richard|date=1983-10-01|title=Ionic selectivity revisited: The role of kinetic and equilibrium processes in ion permeation through channels|journal=The Journal of Membrane Biology|volume=76|issue=3|pages=197–225|doi=10.1007/bf01870364|issn=0022-2631|pmid=6100862}}</ref><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":5">{{Cite journal|last=Krauss|first=Daniel|last2=Eisenberg|first2=Bob|last3=Gillespie|first3=Dirk|date=2011-03-06|title=Selectivity sequences in a model calcium channel: role of electrostatic field strength|journal=European Biophysics Journal|language=en|volume=40|issue=6|pages=775–782|doi=10.1007/s00249-011-0691-6|issn=0175-7571|pmc=3124256|pmid=21380773}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Nadler|first=Boaz|last2=Hollerbach|first2=Uwe|last3=Eisenberg|first3=R. S.|date=2003-08-13|title=Dielectric boundary force and its crucial role in gramicidin|journal=Physical Review E|volume=68|issue=2|pages=021905|doi=10.1103/physreve.68.021905|issn=1063-651X|pmid=14525004|bibcode=2003PhRvE..68b1905N}}</ref>. In the ICB model, this occurs when <math> \Delta E </math> is almost exactly balanced by <math> E_{\rm AFF} </math> (<math>\mu_{\rm ex}\approx0</math>), which happens for a particular value of <math>Q_{\rm f}</math> (Fig.2.) <ref name=":12">{{Cite journal|last=Kaufman|first=I.|last2=Luchinsky|first2=D. G.|last3=Tindjong|first3=R.|last4=McClintock|first4=P. V. E.|last5=Eisenberg|first5=R. S.|date=2013-11-19|title=Energetics of discrete selectivity bands and mutation-induced transitions in the calcium-sodium ion channels family|journal=Physical Review E|volume=88|issue=5|pages=052712|doi=10.1103/PhysRevE.88.052712|pmid=24329301|bibcode=2013PhRvE..88e2712K|arxiv=1305.1847}}</ref>. This resonant value of <math>Q_{\rm f}</math> depends on the ionic properties <math>z</math> and <math>R_{\rm ion}</math> (implicitly, via the <math>R_{\rm ion}</math>-dependent dehydration energy <ref name=":16" /><ref name=":13" />), thereby providing a basis for selectivity.
=== Oscillations of conductance === [[File:Ca Bands. v02.jpg|alt=|thumb|330x330px|Fig.3. Ionic Coulomb blockade illustrated by BD-simulations of Ca<math>^{2+}</math> conduction, as the fixed charge <math>Q_{\rm f}</math> is varied: (a) Ca<math>^{2+}</math> conduction bands; (b) Ca<math>^{2+}</math> occupancy, forming a Coulomb staircase; and (c) Ground state energy (red)]]The ICB model explicitly predicts an oscillatory dependence of conduction on <math>Q_{\rm f}</math>, with two interlaced sets of singularities associated with a sequentially increasing number of ions <math>n=1,2,3,... </math> in the channel (Fig.3A). '''Electrostatic blockade points <math>Q_{\rm f}=Z_n </math>''' correspond to minima in the ground state energy of the pore (Fig.3C).<math display="block">E_{\rm G}(Q_{\rm f}) =\min_n{E_n(Q_{\rm f})} \quad \quad \text{(Ground state})</math> The <math>Z_n </math> points (<math>\partial E_n/\partial Q_{\rm f}=0</math>) are equivalent to neutralisation points<ref name=":12" /> where <math>Q_{n}=0 </math>.
'''Resonant conduction points <math>Q_{\rm f}=M_n </math>''' correspond to the barrier-less condition: <math display="inline">\mu_{\rm ex} =0 </math>, or <math>\Delta E\approx-E_{\rm AFF}</math>.
The values of <math>Z_n \text{ and } M_n</math><ref name="Kaufman:15" /> are given by the simple formulae<math display="block">\begin{align}Z_n&=-z e n &\text{(Electrostatic blockade)} \\ M_n&=-z e (n+1/2) &\text{(Resonant conduction)}, \end{align} </math>i.e. the period of conductance oscillations in <math>Q_{\rm f}</math>, <math>\Delta=|M_{n+1}-M_n|=|Z_{n+1}-Z_n|=|ze| </math>.
For <math>z=2</math>, in a typical ion channel geometry, <math>\Delta E/(k_{\rm B}T) \approx 20 \gg 1</math>, and ICB becomes strong. Consequently, plots of the BD-simulated <chem>Ca^2+</chem>current <math>J</math> ''vs'' <math>Q_{\rm f}</math> exhibit multi-ion conduction bands ''- strong Coulomb blockade oscillations'' between minima <math>Z_n</math>and maxima <math>M_n</math>(Fig.3A)) <ref name=":12" />. The point <math>Z_0 </math> corresponds to an uncharged pore with <math>Q_{\rm f}=0 </math>. Such pores are blockaded for ions of either sign.
=== Coulomb staircase ===
The ICB oscillations in conductance correspond to a ''Coulomb staircase'' in the pore occupancy <math>P_{\rm c}</math>, with transition regions corresponding to <math>M_n</math> and saturation regions corresponding to <math>Z_n</math> (Fig.3B) . The shape of the staircase is described by the [[Fermi–Dirac statistics|Fermi-Dirac]] (FD) distribution<ref name="Kaufman:15" /> , similarly to the Coulomb staircases of quantum dots <ref name=":2" />. Thus, for the <math>0 \rightarrow 1</math> transition, the FD function is: <math display="block">\begin{align} P_{\rm c}&=\left[1+\dfrac{1}{P_{\rm b}}\exp\left(\dfrac{\mu_{\rm ex}}{k_{\rm B}T}\right)\right]^{-1}; &\text{(Fermi-Dirac distribution)}\\ \mu_{\rm ex}&=\phi_s\left( Q_{\rm f}-M_0\right). \end{align}</math>Here <math>\mu_{\rm ex}</math> is the [[excess chemical potential]] for the particular ion and <math>P_{\rm b}</math> is an equivalent bulk occupancy related to pore volume. The saturated FD statistics of occupancy is equivalent to the [[Langmuir isotherm]]<ref name=":17">{{Cite journal|last=Fowler|first=R. H.|date=1935|title=A Statistical Derivation of Langmuir's Adsorption Isotherm|url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/mathematical-proceedings-of-the-cambridge-philosophical-society/article/statistical-derivation-of-langmuirs-adsorption-isotherm/866A71D466CE0EABF6C82A7D8BD5B3E1|journal=Mathematical Proceedings of the Cambridge Philosophical Society|language=en|volume=31|issue=2|pages=260–264|doi=10.1017/S0305004100013359|issn=1469-8064|via=|bibcode=1935PCPS...31..260F}}</ref> or to Michaelis-Menten kinetics.<ref>{{Citation|last=Ainsworth|first=Stanley|date=1977|pages=43–73|publisher=Macmillan Education UK|language=en|doi=10.1007/978-1-349-01959-5_3|isbn=9781349019618|chapter=Michaelis-Menten Kinetics|title=Steady-State Enzyme Kinetics}}</ref>
It is the factor <math>1/P_{\rm b} </math> that gives rise to the concentration-related shift in the staircase seen in Fig.3B.
=== Shift of ICB singular points ===
Addition of the partial excess chemical potentials <math>\mu_{\rm ex}^Y</math> coming from different sources <math>Y </math>(including dehydration,<ref name=":13" /> local binding,<ref name=":6" /> volume exclusion etc.<ref name=":4" /> <ref name=":5" />) leads to the ICB barrier-less condition <math>\mu_{\rm ex}=0</math> leads to a proper shift in the ICB resonant points <math>M_n</math>, described by a "shift equation<nowiki>"</nowiki> : <ref name=":10">{{Cite web|url=https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/abstract/document/7985973/|title=Relation between selectivity and conductivity in narrow ion channels - IEEE Conference Publication|last=Luchinsky|first=D.G,|last2=Gibby W.A.T, Kaufman I.Kh., McClintock P.V.E., Timucin D.A.|date=2017|website=ieeexplore.ieee.org|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref name=":6" /><math display="block">\Delta M_n= -\dfrac{1}{\phi_s} \sum_Y{\mu_{\rm ex}^{Y}} \quad \quad \text{(Shift equation)} </math> i.e. the additional energy contributions <math display="inline">\mu_{\rm ex}^Y</math> lead to shifts in the resonant barrier-less point <math>M_0</math>.
The more important of these shifts (excess potentials) are:
*  A concentration-related shift <math>\mu_{\rm ex}^{\rm ES}=-k_{\rm B}T\log(P_{\rm b})</math> arising from the bulk entropy<ref name=":5" /> *  A dehydration-related shift <math>\mu_{\rm ex}^{\rm DH}</math>, arising from partial dehydration penalty <ref name=":13" /> * A local binding-related shift <math>\mu_{\rm ex}^{\rm INT}</math>, coming from energy of local binding <ref name=":6">{{Cite web|url=https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/abstract/document/7985974/|title=Effect of local binding on stochastic transport in ion channels - IEEE Conference Publication|last=Kaufman|first=I.Kh.|last2=Gibby W.A.T., Luchinsky D.G., McClintock P.V.E.|date=2017|website=ieeexplore.ieee.org|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> and surface effects<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Tanaka|first=Hiroya|last2=Iizuka|first2=Hideo|last3=Pershin|first3=Yuriy V.|last4=Ventra|first4=Massimiliano Di|date=2018|title=Surface effects on ionic Coulomb blockade in nanometer-size pores|url=http://stacks.iop.org/0957-4484/29/i=2/a=025703|journal=Nanotechnology|language=en|volume=29|issue=2|pages=025703|doi=10.1088/1361-6528/aa9a14|pmid=29130892|issn=0957-4484|bibcode=2018Nanot..29b5703T|arxiv=1711.09725}}</ref>.<br />
== ICB in artificial nanopores ==
=== Sub-nm <chem>MoS2</chem>pores === Following its prediction based on analytic theory<ref name=":0" /><ref name="Kaufman:15" /> and molecular dynamics simulations, experimental evidence for ICB emerged from experiments<ref name="Feng:16" /> on monolayer <chem>MoS2</chem> pierced by a single <math>0.6</math>nm nanopore. Highly non-Ohmic conduction was observed between aqueous ionic solutions on either side of the membrane. In particular, for low voltages across the membrane, the current remained close to zero, but it rose abruptly when a threshold of about <math>400</math>mV was exceeded. This was interpreted as complete ionic Coulomb blockade of current in the (uncharged) nanopore due to the large potential barrier at low voltages. But the application of larger voltages pulled the barrier down, producing accessible states into which transitions could occur, thus leading to conduction.
== ICB in biological ion channels == The realisation that ICB could occur in biological ion channels<ref name="Kaufman:15" /> accounted for several experimentally observed features of selectivity, including:
=== Valence selectivity === Valence selectivity is the channel's ability to discriminate between ions of different valence <math>z</math>, wherein e.g. a [[calcium channel]] favours <math>\text{Ca}^{2+}</math> ions over <math>\text{Na}^{+}</math> ions by a factor of up to 1000×.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Sather|first=William A.|last2=McCleskey|first2=Edwin W.|date=2003|title=Permeation and Selectivity in Calcium Channels|journal=Annual Review of Physiology|language=EN|volume=65|issue=1|pages=133–159|doi=10.1146/annurev.physiol.65.092101.142345|pmid=12471162|issn=0066-4278}}</ref> Valence selectivity has been attributed variously to pure electrostatics,<ref name="Corry:05" /> or to a charge space competition mechanism,<ref name="Boda08">{{cite journal |last1=Boda |first1=Dezso |last2=Nonner |first2=Wolfgang |last3=Henderson |first3=Douglas |last4=Eisenberg |first4=Bob |last5=Gillespie |first5=Dirk |title=Volume exclusion in calcium selective channels |journal=Biophysical Journal |date=2008 |volume=94 |issue=9 |pages=3486–3496|bibcode=2008BpJ....94.3486B |doi=10.1529/biophysj.107.122796 |pmid=18199663 |pmc=2292364 }}</ref> or to a snug fit of the ion to ligands,<ref name="dudev2014">{{cite journal |last1=Dudev |first1=Todor |last2=Lim |first2=Carmay |title=Evolution of eukaryotic ion Channels: principles underlying the conversion of Ca<math>^{2+}</math>-selective to Na<math>^+</math>‑selective channels |journal=Journal of the American Chemical Society |date=2014 |volume=136 |issue=9 |pages=3553–559 |doi=10.1021/ja4121132|pmid=24517213 }}</ref> or to quantised dehydration.<ref name="Corry:13">{{cite journal |last1=Corry |first1=Ben |title=Na<math>^+</math>/Ca<math>^{2+}</math> selectivity in the bacterial voltage-gated sodium channel NavAb |journal=Peer J |volume=1 |pages=e16 |date=2013 |doi=10.7717/peerj.16|pmid=23638350 |pmc=3629057 }}</ref> In the ICB model, valence selectivity arises from electrostatics, namely from <math>z</math>-dependence of the value of <math>Q_{\rm f}=M_n=-ze(n+1/2)</math> needed to provide for barrier-less conduction.
Correspondingly, the ICB model provides explanations of why site-directed [[mutations]] that alter <math>Q_{\rm f}</math> can destroy the channel by blockading it, or can alter its selectivity from favouring <math>\text{Ca}^{2+}</math> ions to favouring <math>\text{Na}^{+}</math> ions, or ''vice versa'' <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Heinemann|first=Stefan H.|last2=Terlau|first2=Heinrich|last3=Stühmer|first3=Walter|last4=Imoto|first4=Keiji|last5=Numa|first5=Shosaku|date=1992|title=Calcium channel characteristics conferred on the sodium channel by single mutations|url=https://www.nature.com/articles/356441a0|journal=Nature|language=En|volume=356|issue=6368|pages=441–443|doi=10.1038/356441a0|pmid=1313551|issn=0028-0836|via=|bibcode=1992Natur.356..441H}}</ref>''.''
=== Divalent blockade === Divalent (e.g. <math>\text{Ca}^{2+}</math>) blockade of monovalent (e.g. <math>\text{Na}^{+}</math>) currents is observed in some types of ion channel. Namely, <math>\text{Na}^{+}</math> ions in a pure sodium solution pass unimpeded through a [[calcium channel]], but are blocked by tiny (nM) extracellular concentrations of <math>\text{Ca}^{2+}</math> ions. ICB provides a transparent explanation of both the phenomenon itself and of the Langmuir-isotherm-shape of the current ''vs.'' <math>\log[\text{Ca}^{2+}]</math> attenuation curve, deriving them from the strong affinity and an FD distribution of <chem>Ca^2+</chem>ions.<ref name="Kaufman:15" /><ref name=":8">{{Cite journal|last=Kaufman|first=Igor Kh.|last2=Fedorenko|first2=Olena A.|last3=Luchinsky|first3=Dmitri G.|last4=Gibby|first4=William A.T.|last5=Roberts|first5=Stephen K.|last6=McClintock|first6=Peter V.E.|last7=Eisenberg|first7=Robert S.|date=2017|title=Ionic Coulomb blockade and anomalous mole fraction effect in the NaChBac bacterial ion channel and its charge-varied mutants|journal=EPJ Nonlinear Biomedical Physics|language=en|volume=5|pages=4|doi=10.1051/epjnbp/2017003|issn=2195-0008}}</ref> Similarly, ICB can account for the divalent (Iodide <chem>I^2-</chem>) blockade that has been observed in biological chloride (<chem>Cl-</chem>)-selective channels.<ref name=":15" />
== Special features ==
=== Comparisons between ICB and ECB === ICB and ECB should be considered as two versions of the same fundamental electrostatic phenomenon. Both ICB and ECB are based on charge quantisation and on the finite single-particle charging energy <math>\Delta E </math>, resulting in close similarity of the governing equations and manifestations of these closely related phenomena. Nonetheless, there are important distinctions between ICB and ECB: their similarities and differences are summarised in Table 1. {| class="wikitable" |+ Table 1. Comparison between ICB and ECB !Property !ICB !ECB |- |Mobile charge carriers |cations (<math>\text{Na}^+, \text{K}^+, \text{Ca}^{2+},</math> etc...), anions (<math>\text{Cl}^-, \text{I}^{2-},</math> etc.) |electrons (<math>e^-</math>) |- |Valence of mobile charge carriers, <math>z</math> |positive (+1, +2, +3,...), negative (-1, -2...) |<math>z=-1</math> |- |Transport engine |Classical diffusion |QM tunneling |- |Conductance oscillations |Yes, valence dependent |Yes |- |Coulomb staircase for occupancy, <math>P_c</math> |Yes, FD-shaped |Yes, FD-shaped |} === Quantum analogies in ICB === Despite appearing in completely [[Classical mechanics|classical systems]], ICB exhibits some phenomena reminiscent of [[Quantum mechanics|quantum-mechanics]] (QM). They arise because the charge/entity discreteness of the ions leads to quantisation of the energy <math>\Delta E</math> spectrum and hence to the QM-analogies:<ref name=":7">{{Cite arxiv|last=Meyertholen|first=Andrew|last2=Di Ventra|first2=Massimiliano|date=2013-05-31|title=Quantum Analogies in Ionic Transport Through Nanopores|eprint=1305.7450|class=cond-mat.mes-hall}}</ref>
* Noise-driven diffusive motion provides for escape over barriers, comparable to QM-tunnelling in ECB. * The particular FD shape<ref name="Kaufman:15" /> of the <math>\text {Ca}^{2+}</math> occupancy ''vs'' <math>\log{[\text{Ca}^{2+}]}</math> plays a significant role in the ICB explanation of the divalent blockade phenomenon. <ref name=":8" /> The appearance of an FD distribution in the diffusion of classical particles obeying an [[Exclusion principle (philosophy)|exclusion principle]], has been demonstrated rigorously.<ref name=":17" /><ref name=":9">{{Cite journal|last=Kaniadakis|first=G.|last2=Quarati|first2=P.|date=1993-12-01|title=Kinetic equation for classical particles obeying an exclusion principle|journal=Physical Review E|volume=48|issue=6|pages=4263–4270|doi=10.1103/PhysRevE.48.4263|bibcode=1993PhRvE..48.4263K}}</ref>

Its principal activity is the production, marketing and sale of Isuzu commercial vehicles and diesel engines. It also has a number of subsidiaries, included [[Isuzu (Anadolu)|Anadolu Isuzu]] (a Turkish joint venture with Anadolu Group), [[Sollers-Isuzu]] (a Russian joint venture with [[Sollers JSC]]), [[SML Isuzu]] (formerly [[Swaraj Mazda]]), [[Jianxi Isuzu Motors]] (a Chinese joint venture with [[Jiangling Motors|Jiangling Motors Company Group]]), [[Isuzu Astra Motor Indonesia]], [[Isuzu Malaysia]] ([[Isuzu HICOM Malaysia|Isuzu HICOM]]), [[Isuzu Truck (UK)|Isuzu UK]], [[Isuzu Truck South Africa|Isuzu South Africa]], [[Isuzu Philippines]], [[Taiwan Isuzu Motors]], [[Isuzu Vietnam]], and [[Isuzu Motors India]]. Isuzu has assembly and manufacturing plants in [[Fujisawa, Kanagawa|Fujisawa]], as well as in the [[Tochigi Prefecture|Tochigi]] and [[Hokkaidō]] prefectures. Isuzu-branded vehicles are sold in most commercial markets worldwide. Isuzu's primary market focus is on commercial diesel-powered truck, buses and construction, while their Japanese competitor [[Yanmar]] focuses on commercial-level powerplants and generators. By 2009, Isuzu had produced over 21 million diesel engines, which can be found in vehicles all over the world.{{cite web|url=http://www.isuzu.co.jp/world/corporate/engine/worldclass.html |title=Isuzu.co.jp |publisher=Isuzu.co.jp |date= |accessdate=2010-11-29}} Isuzu diesel engines are used by dozens of vehicle manufacturers, including [[Ford Motor Company]]{{citation needed|date=September 2017}} and the [[Renault–Nissan–Mitsubishi Alliance]].{{citation needed|date=September 2017}} ==History== Isuzu Motors' history began in 1916, when Tokyo [[IHI Corporation|Ishikawajima]] Shipbuilding and Engineering Co., Ltd. planned a cooperation with the Tokyo Gas and Electric Industrial Co. to build automobiles. The next step was taken in 1918, when a technical cooperation with [[Wolseley Motors|Wolseley Motors Limited]] was initiated, yielding exclusive rights to the production and sales of Wolseley vehicles in East Asia.{{cite book | ref = Ruiz | last = Ruiz | first = Marco | title = 'The Complete History of the Japanese Car: 1907 to the Present | publisher = ERVIN srl | location = Rome | year = 1986 | page = 130 | isbn = 0-517-61777-3 }} In 1922 came the first ever Japan-produced passenger car, a Wolseley model, the A9.[http://www.isuzu.co.jp/world/corporate/truck/builders01.html Isuzu Website] The CP [[truck]] followed two years later; 550 of these were built by 1927.{{Cite journal | title = トラックメーカーアーカイブ: いすゞ自動車のすべて [Truck Manufacturer Archive: Everything Isuzu] | ref = Ishikawa | last = Ishikawa | first = Kenji | language = Japanese | work = Camion | publisher = Geibun Mooks | location = Tokyo, Japan | page = 98 | date = 2012-05-01 | isbn = 978-4-86396-183-8 | postscript = {{inconsistent citations}} }} In 1933, Ishikawajima Automotive Works merged with DAT Automobile Manufacturing Inc. (a predecessor of [[Nissan]]) and changed its name to Automobile Industries Co., Ltd. The products of this company, marketed as "Sumiya" and "Chiyoda", were renamed '''Isuzu''' (after the [[Isuzu River]]) in 1934, following a meeting with the Japanese Government's [[Ministry of International Trade and Industry|Ministry of Trade and Industry (MITI)]]. The word Isuzu translated into English means "fifty bells"—hence the focus on "bell" in both the later [[Isuzu Bellel|Bellel]] and the [[Isuzu Bellett|Bellett]]. {{triple image|left|1st_ISUZU_LOGO,_1949-1974.jpg|110|OLD_ISUZU_LOGO,_1974-1991_(YABANE-MARK).jpg|121|ISUZU,_Existing_logo_from_1991.jpg|110|The first Isuzu emblem, 1949–1974|Second generation Isuzu emblem, 1974–1991|Current Isuzu emblem, 1991–}} In 1937 Automobile Industries was reorganized and formed into a new company, Tokyo Automobile Industries Co., Ltd. It was founded with a capital of ¥1,000,000. Only in 1949 was Isuzu finally adopted as the company name. Meanwhile, in 1942, [[Hino Motors|Hino Heavy Industries]] was split off from Isuzu, becoming a separate corporation.{{cite web |url=http://www.isuzu.co.jp/world/investor/fact/history.html | title = Investor Relations: Company History | publisher = Isuzu Motors | accessdate = 2012-08-28 }} Truck production ([[:ja:いすゞ・TX|TX40 and TU60]]) began anew in 1945, with the permission of the [[Supreme Commander for the Allied Powers|occupation authorities]].[[#Ishikawa|Ishikawa]], p. 7 Beginning in 1953 the [[Hillman Minx]] passenger car is produced under license of [[Rootes Group]]. The Minx remained in production until 1962, after the 1961 introduction of Isuzu's first own car, the [[Isuzu Bellel|Bellel]]. Being a small producer making cars which were somewhat too large and pricey for the Japanese market at the time, Isuzu spent some time looking for a commercial partner. Under pressure from MITI, who were attempting to limit the number of automobile manufacturers in Japan, a cooperation with [[Fuji Heavy Industries]] ([[Subaru]]) began in 1966. This joint sales-service collaboration was seen as the first step towards an eventual merger.{{cite magazine | magazine = [[Road & Track]] | first = Jack | last = Yamaguchi | page = 113 | date = February 1968 | title = 14th Tokyo Motor Show: & Still Trying Harder }} The [[Subaru 1000]] was even shown in Isuzu's 1967 annual vehicle brochure, as a suitable complement to the larger Isuzu lineup.{{Cite journal | title =Isuzu | publisher = Isuzu Motors | language = Japanese |date=October 1967 | pages = 8–9 | type = brochure | id = 42.10 }} This tie-up was over by 1968, when an agreement with [[Mitsubishi]] was formed. This ended even quicker, by 1969, and the next year an equally short-lived collaboration was entered with [[Nissan]].[[#Ruiz|Ruiz]], p. 131 A few months later, in September 1971, what was to prove a more durable capital agreement was signed with [[General Motors Corporation|General Motors]]. ===Linking with General Motors=== The first result of GM taking a 34% stake in Isuzu is seen in 1972, only months later, when the [[Chevrolet LUV]] becomes the first Isuzu-built vehicle to be sold in the United States. To symbolize the new beginning, Isuzu also developed a new logo for 1974, with two vertical pillars which are stylized representations of the first syllable in いすゞ ("Isuzu"). In 1974 Isuzu introduced the [[Isuzu Gemini|Gemini]], which was co-produced with General Motors as the [[GM T platform (1973)|T-car]]. It was sold in the United States as [[Buick]]'s Opel by Isuzu, and in Australia as the Holden Gemini. As a result of the collaboration, certain American GM products are sold to Japanese customers through Isuzu dealerships. Holden's [[Statesman (automobile)|Statesman]] was also briefly sold (246 examples) with Isuzu badging in Japan during the seventies.{{cite book | last = Bedwell | first = Steve | year = 2009 | title = Holden vs Ford: the cars, the culture, the competition | location = [[Dulwich Hill, New South Wales]] | publisher = Rockpool | isbn = 978-1-921295-17-1 | page = 199 }} Isuzu exports also increased considerably as a result of being able to use GM networks, from 0.7% of production in 1973 to 35.2% by 1976; this while overall production increased more than fourfold in the same period. As a result of the GM joint venture, Isuzu engines were also used by existing GM divisions (some USA-market Chevrolet automobiles had Isuzu powertrains e.g. the Chevette and early S10/S15 trucks manufactured prior to 1985). [[File:1966 Isuzu Bellett 01.jpg|thumb|1966 Isuzu Bellett 1600 GT (PR90)]] In 1981 Isuzu began selling consumer and commercial vehicles under their own brand in the United States. The [[Isuzu P'Up]] was the first model sold to consumers as an Isuzu, rather than as a [[Chevrolet]] or Buick. Isuzu's then president Toshio Okamoto then initiated a collaboration with small-car expert [[Suzuki]] to develop a global small car for GM, the [[GM S platform|S-car]].{{cite journal | title = GM ties with two Japanese car makers | location = Tokyo | date = 1981-08-18 | page = 1 | journal = [[Nihon Keizai Shimbun]] }} A three-way agreement of co-ownership was signed in August 1981, with Isuzu and Suzuki exchanging shares and General Motors taking a 5% share of Suzuki. Following on from this, in 1985 Isuzu and GM established the [[IBC Vehicles]] venture in the United Kingdom, producing locally built versions of Isuzu and Suzuki light vans (the [[Isuzu Fargo]] and [[Suzuki Carry]]); to be sold in the European market under [[Vauxhall Motors|Vauxhall]]'s [[Bedford Vehicles|Bedford]] brand. During this period Isuzu also developed a worldwide presence as an exporter of diesel engines, with their powerplants in use by [[Opel]]/Vauxhall, [[Land Rover]], [[Hindustan Motors|Hindustan]], and many others. Two Isuzu model lines (Gemini, Impulse) were marketed as part of the [[Geo (automobile)|Geo]] division (Spectrum, Storm) when it was initially launched as a Chevrolet subsidiary. In the domestic Japanese market, OEM deals with other manufacturers were entered to aid the poorly performing passenger car arm. It led to the badging of Suzukis, beginning in 1986,{{cite journal | title = Isuzu, Suzuki tie up in sales and production | location = Tokyo | date = 1986-01-18 | section = Machinery | page = 10 | journal = [[Nihon Keizai Shimbun]] }} and Subaru small commercial vehicles as Isuzus ([[Suzuki Cultus|Geminett]], [[Subaru Leone#third|Geminett II]]). This OEM tie-up occurred alongside the establishment of SIA (Subaru-Isuzu Automotive), an American joint venture with Fuji Heavy Industries (the parent company of [[Subaru]]). Shortly afterwards, the [[Lafayette, Indiana]] plant became operational. ===Contraction begins=== [[File:Isuzu Unicab 2.jpg|thumb|1967 [[:ja:いすゞ・ユニキャブ|Isuzu Unicab]], a two-wheel-drive utility vehicle]] Isuzu ended US sales of the [[Isuzu Impulse|Impulse]] ([[Geo Storm]]) in 1992, and the following year it stopped exporting the [[Isuzu Stylus|Stylus]] (the basis for the [[Geo Spectrum]]), the last Isuzu-built car sold in the US. In 1993 Isuzu began a new vehicle exchange program with [[Honda]], whereby Honda sold the [[Isuzu Rodeo]]{{cite news|url=http://www.cars.com/isuzu/rodeo/1993/expert-reviews|title=Expert Reviews: 1993 Isuzu Rodeo|author=Truett, Richard Truett|work=Orlando Sentinel|date=October 21, 1993 }} and [[Isuzu Trooper]] as the [[Honda Passport]] and [[Acura SLX]], respectively. In return Isuzu began selling the [[Honda Odyssey (North America)|Honda Odyssey]] as the Isuzu Oasis. Thus, Honda's lineup gained two SUVs, and Isuzu's lineup gained a minivan. In the Japanese market, the Gemini (Stylus) was now a rebadged [[Honda Domani]] and the Aska (originally based on the GM [[GM J platform|J-car]]) was a [[Honda Accord]]. Isuzu's United States sales reached a peak in 1996 after the introduction of the [[Isuzu Hombre]] pickup, a badge-engineered GM truck (using the sheetmetal of the Brazil-market Chevrolet S10). Isuzu resurrected the beloved Amigo in 1998, before changing the name of the 2-door convertible to Rodeo Sport in 2001 in an attempt to associate it with the better selling 4-door Rodeo. The Rodeo Sport was discontinued in 2003, while production of the Rodeo and Axiom ceased a year later. By this point sales in North America had slowed to just 27,188, with the discontinued Rodeo and Axiom making up 71% of that total. In 1998 [[General Motors Corporation|General Motors]] and Isuzu formed [[DMAX (engines)|DMAX]], a joint venture to produce [[diesel engine]]s. GM raised its stake in Isuzu to 49% the following year, effectively gaining control of the company and quickly followed this up by appointing an American GM executive to head Isuzu's North American Operations. This marked the first time a non-Japanese executive had ever held such a high position at Isuzu. In 2001 G.M. and Isuzu announced plans to share distribution networks and for Chevrolet to market an Isuzu product. The production version of the heralded [[Isuzu VehiCROSS|VehiCROSS]] was introduced to the US in 1999, but met with mixed reviews, as its high pricetag, unique styling and two-door configuration did not seem to meet with market demands. Production of the VehiCROSS and other sport utility vehicles, including the [[Isuzu Trooper|Trooper]], ended in 2001 as part of a major financial reorganization which eliminated almost 10,000 jobs.{{cite news|last1=Krebs|first1=Michelle|title=Isuzu's U.S. Presence Leans on G.M.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2001/07/01/automobiles/isuzu-s-us-presence-leans-on-gm.html|accessdate=23 September 2017|work=The New York Times|date=1 Jul 2001}} GM had been pushing the company to focus exclusively on producing commercial vehicles and engines. {{prose|section|date=November 2010}} * 2001 – [[Joe Isuzu]], the immensely popular pitchman with implausible claims, is hired once again to promote the new [[Isuzu Axiom|Axiom]]. Isuzu sales begin to slide due to the aging of the [[Isuzu Rodeo|Rodeo]] and [[Isuzu Trooper|Trooper]], and poor management & lack of assistance from GM. Its Duramax engines in full-size pickup trucks have won rave reviews. * Early 2002 – Fuji Heavy Industries (Subaru's parent company) buys Isuzu's share of Lafayette, Indiana plant. Subaru Isuzu Automotive (SIA) becomes [[Subaru of Indiana Automotive]]. After 8 years of heavy Honda Passport sales and light Isuzu Oasis sales, Honda and Isuzu cooperatively end their vehicle exchange agreement. The Oasis is dropped, and Honda replaces the Passport with the Pilot. Also, it was Isuzu's last year for passenger vehicles in Canada, as Isuzus in Canada were mostly sold at [[Saturn Corporation|Saturn]]-[[Saab Automobile|Saab]] dealerships. * Late 2002 – Isuzu initiates a recapitalization and [[Debt restructuring#Debt-for-equity swap|debt-for-equity conversion]] plan to stave off a bankruptcy. GM acquires 20% of [[DMAX (engines)|DMAX]], 60% of [[Isuzu Motors Polska]] and Isuzu Motors Germany, and the rights to three types of diesel engine technology from Isuzu.{{cite web|title=Press Release: Isuzu Motors Limited Unveils the New Three-year Business Plan and Re-capitalization Plan, involving Decrease of Capital and Debt-for-equity Conversion.|url=http://www.isuzu.co.jp/world/press/2002/p_1025.html|website=www.Isuzu.co.jp|publisher=Isuzu Motors|accessdate=23 September 2017}} by paying 50 billion yen (about US$425 million).{{cite news|title=Isuzu falls back after GM rescue plan|url=http://www.cnn.com/2002/BUSINESS/asia/08/15/japan.isuzu.biz/index.html|accessdate=23 September 2017|publisher=CNN.com|date=15 Aug 2002}} GM also pays 10 billion yen (about US$85 million) for a 12% stake in the recapitalized company. G.M. wrote off its investment in Isuzu in 2001.{{cite news|last1=Belson|first1=Ken|title=G.M. Moves to Increase Control of Some Isuzu Units|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/08/15/business/gm-moves-to-increase-control-of-some-isuzu-units.html?mcubz=3|accessdate=23 September 2017|work=The New York Times|date=15 Aug 2002}} * 2004 – The number of Isuzu dealerships in the U.S. begins a rapid decline. * 2005 – Isuzu dealers in the United States have only 2 models: the Ascender and the i-series pickup truck. The i-series is a rebadged Chevrolet Colorado, the Ascender is a re-badged GMC Envoy. At this point, Isuzu in the United States is primarily a distributor of medium duty trucks such as the [[Isuzu Elf|N-series]]. These vehicles are sourced both from Japan and U.S. plants in Janesville, Wisconsin and Flint, Michigan. Isuzu has 290 light-vehicle dealers in the U.S. as of August 2006, and sells an average of just two Ascenders per dealer per month. Plans to introduce a new Thai-built [[Sport utility vehicle|SUV]], expected to be added for 2007, are shelved; Isuzu Motors Limited believes that a new SUV would be too risky and proceeds with the launch of the i-series trucks. Rumors of Isuzu's withdrawal from the U.S. market are rampant. Despite extremely low sales figures of 12,177 passenger vehicles for 2005 (with leftover Axiom and Rodeos making up 30% of this), Isuzu Motors America announces its first profit in years, mainly due to restructuring cuts. * 2006 – Production of the 7-passenger Ascender ends in February with the closure of GM's [[Oklahoma City Assembly]] plant, leaving Isuzu with the 5-passenger Ascender, built in [[Moraine, Ohio]] and the low-selling i-Series as its only retail products. The company sold just 1,504 vehicles in North America in the first two months of 2006. GM ends its equity investment in Isuzu and sells all its shares to [[Mitsubishi Corporation]], [[Itochu]] and [[Mizuho Corporate Bank]], both GM and Isuzu claims the companies will continue their current relationship. There is no word as of April 12, 2006 on the effect this will have on [[DMAX (engines)|DMAX]] operations. [[File:ISUZU LT132L.JPG|thumb|Isuzu LT132L on a [[Hong Kong]] motorway]] [[File:ISUZU BMTA LV486R.JPG|thumb|Isuzu LV486R CNG City Bus in [[Bangkok]] with the CNG-MPI Engine]] * June 2006 – Isuzu and GM agree to establish a joint venture called "LCV Platform Engineering Corporation (LPEC)" to develop a new pickup. Isuzu says it will use its engineering expertise to develop the pickup and GM will develop derivatives based on the integrated platform. * October 2006 – Mitsubishi Corp. becomes Isuzu's largest shareholder, after it converts all the preferred share in Isuzu it has held since 2005 into common stock, increasing its shareholding from 3.5% to 15.65%.{{cite web|title=Mitsubish becomes top shareholder of Isuzu|url=http://www.autoblog.com/2006/10/04/mitsubish-becomes-top-shareholder-of-isuzu/|website=Autoblog|accessdate=26 April 2016}} * November 2006 – Toyota purchases 5.9% of Isuzu, becoming the third largest shareholder behind [[Itochu]] and [[Mitsubishi Corporation]], and the two companies agree to study possible business collaboration focusing on the areas of R&D and production of diesel engines, related emissions-control, and other environmental technologies. * January 2007 – Isuzu and General Motors update the LCV range with a 3.0 litre common rail diesel engine that has far more torque and power than its predecessor. * August 2007 – Isuzu and Toyota agree to develop a 1.6-liter diesel engine for use in Toyota vehicles sold in European markets. Details of development, production and supply of the diesel engine, are still under discussion, but in principle, Isuzu will play the leading role. Production is scheduled to begin around 2012. * January 30, 2008 – Isuzu announces complete withdrawal from the US market,{{cite news|title=Isuzu quitting U.S. car market|publisher=Los Angeles Times|url=http://www.latimes.com/classified/automotive/highway1/la-hy-isuzu31jan31,0,168226.story|accessdate=2008-01-30 | first=Ken | last=Bensinger | date=January 31, 2008}} effective January 31, 2009. It will continue to provide support and parts. The decision was due to lack of sales.{{cite web|last=Johnson |first=Drew |url=http://www.leftlanenews.com/isuzu-to-leave-us-market.html |title=Isuzu to leave U.S. market |publisher=Leftlanenews.com |date=2008-01-30 |accessdate=2012-02-05}} Some of the lack of sales have been blamed on consumer experiences with low quality engines and service.{{cite web|url=http://www.consumeraffairs.com/automotive/isuzu_engine.html |title=Consumer complaints about Isuzu - Engine Failure |publisher=Consumeraffairs.com |date= |accessdate=2012-02-05}} Isuzu had been experiencing a slow decline since the late 1990s. In less than 10 years, they had gone from selling a complete line of cars, trucks, and SUVs, into being a specialized SUV maker, and finally selling only a pair of rebadged, General Motors Trucks.{{cite web|last=Neff |first=John |url=http://www.autoblog.com/2008/01/30/confirmed-isuzu-abandoning-u-s-market/ |title=CONFIRMED: Isuzu abandoning U.S. market |publisher=Autoblog |date=2008-01-30 |accessdate=2010-11-29}} They will continue to sell commercial vehicles in the U.S.{{cite web|url=https://www.cnbc.com/id/22920144/for/cnbc |title=Isuzu executive says competition helped push it out of North American market - MSNBC Wire Services - MSNBC.com |publisher=Cnbc.com |date= |accessdate=2010-11-29}} {{Dead link|date=December 2012}} * December 17, 2008 – Isuzu, Toyota shelve development of clean diesel engine.{{cite web|url=http://www.industryweek.com/companies-amp-executives/isuzu-toyota-shelve-development-clean-diesel-engine|title=Isuzu, Toyota Shelve Development of Clean Diesel Engine | industryweek.com | Industry Week|publisher=industryweek.com |date=2008-12-16|accessdate=2011-05-21}} * January 29, 2009 – Isuzu and General Motors announce that they were in talks to transfer the operation of the medium-duty truck production line in [[Flint, Michigan]] to Isuzu for a five-year period. In June, however, GM announced that these talks failed to reach an agreement, and GM instead ceased production of the [[Chevrolet Kodiak]] and GMC Topkick vehicles on 31 July 2009.{{cite web|url=http://www.detnews.com/article/20090609/AUTO01/906090330 |title=GM drops medium-duty trucks, opens battery lab | detnews.com | The Detroit News |publisher=detnews.com |date=2009-06-09 |accessdate=2009-12-04}} * July 2016 Isuzu and Mazda agree to collaborate and Isuzu will produce the next-generation pickup trucks for Mazda outside North America. * Isuzu’s plant in the [[India]]n state of [[Andhra Pradesh]] began operations in 2016 [http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/industry/auto/news/industry/isuzu-motors-opens-manufacturing-plant-in-andhra-pradesh/articleshow/52007770.cms Isuzu Motors opens manufacturing plant in Andhra Pradesh], ''[[The Economic Times|Economic Times]]'', April 27, 2016 ==Market presence== [[File:MHV Isuzu Gemini II.01.jpg|thumb|Isuzu Gemini with European (Maltese) registration plates]] [[File:MHV Isuzu NHR Panel Van 01.jpg|thumb|Isuzu NHR (Elf) light truck]] In most of [[Asia]] and [[Africa]], Isuzu is mostly known for trucks of all sizes, after Isuzu small automobile sales drastically plummeted and Isuzu had to drop all sales of sedans and compact cars in the late 1990s. In the days when Isuzu sold passenger cars, they were known for focusing on the [[Diesel engine|diesel-engined]] niche. In 1983, for instance, long before the explosion in diesel sales, diesels represented 63.4% of their passenger car production.{{Cite book | first = Jack K. | last = Yamaguchi | editor-last = Lösch | editor-first = Annamaria | title = Technology On Full Boost | journal = World Cars 1984 | publisher = L'Editrice dell'Automobile LEA/Herald Books | location = Pelham, NY | page = 66 | year = 1984 | isbn = 0-910714-16-9 }} In 2009, Isuzu abandoned the United States consumer market due to lack of sales. Isuzu as a corporation has always been primarily a manufacturer of small to medium compact automobiles and commercial trucks of sizes medium duty and larger, but markets around the world show different needs. Isuzu Motors America discontinued the sale of passenger vehicles in the United States effective January 31, 2009. The company explained to its dealers that it had not been able to secure replacements for the [[Isuzu Ascender]] and [[Isuzu i-Series]] that would be commercially viable. Isuzu sold 7,098 cars in the year 2007. This action did not affect Isuzu's commercial vehicle or industrial diesel engine operations in the United States. Isuzu has a contract with [[Budget Truck Rental]] to manufacture their rental trucks, shared with [[Ford Motor Company|Ford]], [[GMC (General Motors division)|GMC]], and [[Navistar International]].{{cite web |url=http://www.budgettruck.com/Company-Info.aspx |title=Company Info - Budget Truck Rental |publisher=Budgettruck.com |date=2007-12-30 |accessdate=2010-11-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070722075532/http://www.budgettruck.com/Company-Info.aspx |archivedate=2007-07-22 |df= }} In Australia, Isuzu was for many years a major supplier of light commercial and domestic vehicles to [[Holden]] (General Motors). However, by 2008, Holden was sourcing few Isuzus. At this time Isuzu began to sell the D-Max under the Isuzu name. Isuzu's entry in the Thai market proved to be one of its most successful. Its presence in the country began in 1966 when it established a manufacturing facility for pick-up trucks in the [[Samut Prakan Province|Samuthprakarn]] province with a capacity of 155,000 units per year.{{Cite book|title=Facets of Competitiveness: Narratives from ASEAN|last=Lall|first=Ashish|publisher=World Scientific|year=2011|isbn=9789814324113|location=Hackensack, NJ|pages=66}} The automaker quickly became a market leader so that by 2002, the company transferred its production base from its original location in [[Fujisawa, Kanagawa|Fujisuwa, Japan]] to Thailand. Isuzu claimed the largest share of the Thai commercial vehicle market, outperforming its competitors for at least 23 years. By 2006, the company transferred to an industrial zone in [[Chachoengsao Province|Chacheongsao]] province to support further production expansion. By 2017, Isuzu has been exporting pick-up trucks, with shipments reaching North America, Latin America, Australia, and Japan.{{Cite web|url=https://asia.nikkei.com/Economy/Isuzu-interim-profit-seen-climbing-7-as-Thai-sales-recover|title=Isuzu interim profit seen climbing 7% as Thai sales recover|last=|first=|date=November 3, 2017|website=Nikkei Asian Review|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=August 17, 2018}} It the same year, it announced that its profit climbed 7 percent and has doubled its annual truck production to meet overseas demands.{{Cite news|url=https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2017/05/02/business/corporate-business/isuzu-double-heavy-truck-production-thailand-boost-exports/|title=Isuzu to double heavy truck production in Thailand, boost exports|date=2017-05-02|work=The Japan Times Online|access-date=2018-08-17|language=en-US|issn=0447-5763}} ==Subsidiaries and joint ventures== [http://www.isuzu.co.jp/world/investor/fact/facilities.html List of Isuzu Japanese facilities] ===Japan=== The Fujisawa Plant was built and opened for production November 1961. It is located at Tsuchidana, [[Fujisawa, Kanagawa]], and is still producing commercial vehicles for domestic Japanese use and international exports. The Toghichi Plant, located at Hakuchu, [[Ōhira, Tochigi|Ohira-Machi]], [[Tochigi, Tochigi]], is where the engines are currently built. ===Mimamori-kun Online service=== Mimamori-kun, which means to watch, monitor, or observe in [[Japanese language|Japanese]], (literally "Mr. Watcher")[http://www.isuzu.co.jp/world//press/2007/p_0531.html Official press release from Isuzu concerning Mimamori-kun] is a commercial vehicle telematics service developed by Isuzu Motors for monitoring and tracking commercial vehicle operations and movements in Japan. The service uses [[GPS]] satellite tracking services, and began February 2004. It is connected to the internet and provides government mandated [[Hours of service|driver activity logs]], and records how long the driver was on-duty and how much time was spent driving. The service also records when the driver took lunch breaks, where the truck stopped and for how long, and when the driver logged off for his duty shift. The service has been modified for personal use in Japan to keep track of family members, to include elderly members of health status and location of children for safety purposes.[http://www.mimamori-kun.com/ Mimamori-kun personal service (Japanese)] Some of the main features include Internet [[Digital Tachograph]], the first of its kind wirelessly in Japan, combined with hands-free communication, voice guidance, and text messages displayed from the dispatch office. The system also has a password enabled vehicle theft prevention feature that will not let the vehicle start without the driver having entered a password. ====See also==== * [[Telematics]] * [[Field service management]] * [[Field force automation]] * [[Mobile enterprise application framework]] * [[Mobile asset management]] ===International efforts=== * [[DMAX (engines)]] -
